_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Tallgrass Terminals, LLC - Sterling Butane facility handles Butane liquids that are stored

on site and injected into the Crude oil. The facility stores up to 520,000 pounds (lbs.) of

Butane which is split between two 60,000 gallon storage vessels and piping.



Process Controls are in place at the facility, to prevent or minimize an emergency release, including

various automatic and manual shutoffs, alarms, vents, relief and check valves, excess flow devices,

and grounding equipment. In addition, the facility is equipped with UV/IR detection and LEL/HAM

(Hazardous Atmosphere Monitors).



The Worst Case Scenario was assumed to be 80% of the total quantity of one of the 60,000 gallon Butane

bulk storage tanks forming a vapor cloud within the lower and upper flammability limits which

detonates. For flammable substances, the endpoint is overpressure of 1 pound per square inch for

vapor cloud explosions. Under EPA requirements the WCS assumes weather conditions that allow

the chemical to travel as far as possible, and further assumes that none of the facility's mechanical

controls or safety systems are functioning. Based on these assumptions, the WCS vapor cloud

explosion would not reach any residences, commercial or industrial areas since they are all outside of 

the .5 mile endpoint. The process controls mentioned in the previous paragraph minimize the potential 

for the WCS to occur.



The facility complies with Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) regulations,

including the Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements. Facility personnel undergo

operaitons competency training and testing including emergency response drills. The response

training and drills program includes notification to local emergency response agencies as available

during the response training. In addition, the facility is inspected and audited on a compliance schedule

according to the PSM requirements. A Process Hazard Analysis / Hazop is conducted at leas

t

every five years as part of the OSHA PSM requirements as well.



The facility has not experienced any covered process releases.
